meta.title: Foraging Tips from Eat the Weeds

safety_rules.title: The I.T.E.M. System
safety_rules.content: Essential framework for safe foraging: (I)dentify with absolute certainty, (T)ime - verify correct season, (E)nvironment - ensure clean water/soil, (M)ethod - follow specific preparation requirements.

safety_rules.title: Consult Local Experts
safety_rules.content: Never eat a wild plant without consulting a local expert first. Contact your local Native Plant Society.

safety_rules.title: Wait Before Eating
safety_rules.content: Wait at least one week between identification and consumption, even if confident.

safety_rules.title: Start with Small Portions
safety_rules.content: You may have individual reactions even to edible plants. Test with small amounts first.

safety_rules.title: Avoid Field Testing
safety_rules.content: You should know every plant you put in your mouth. No exceptions. Humans can survive 3-4 weeks without food - risking plant poisoning isn't necessary.

safety_rules.title: Taste Is Not an Indicator
safety_rules.content: Many deadly plants taste excellent (hemlock, yew nuts, rosary pea). Some toxic plants kill within 15 minutes; others take weeks.

safety_rules.title: White Sap Warning
safety_rules.content: Almost all plants with white sap are inedible.

safety_rules.title: White Berries Are Toxic
safety_rules.content: White berries are 99.9999% toxic - avoid them entirely.

safety_rules.title: The Mint Rule
safety_rules.content: If it looks like a mint AND smells like a mint, it is a mint and is edible. But it must do BOTH. Same applies to garlic and onions.

safety_rules.title: Mallow Family Safety
safety_rules.content: All mallows are edible (except cotton) in some form.

location_tips.title: Good Foraging Locations
location_tips.content: Scout diverse locations: yards, parks, fields, vacant lots, cemeteries, bike trails, business backs, neighborhoods, abandoned groves, woods, and waterways.

location_tips.title: Avoid Parking Lot Runoff
location_tips.content: Skip lands with parking lot runoff or areas downhill from interstates.

location_tips.title: Railroads Are Toxic
location_tips.content: Railroad lines, even old ones, are extremely toxic. Railroads rank among the most toxic property in the United States.

location_tips.title: Assess Water Quality
location_tips.content: Evaluate water sources carefully - springs differ significantly from ditches in safety.

location_tips.title: Ask Permission
location_tips.content: Request homeowner consent before harvesting from private property. Ask about pesticide use on lawns.

location_tips.title: Avoid Golf Courses
location_tips.content: Golf courses use heavy pesticides - avoid foraging there.

equipment_tips.title: Carry a Permanent Marker
equipment_tips.content: An ultra fine point permanent marker will write on anything - use for labeling samples with dates and locations.

equipment_tips.title: Camera Close-Up Test
equipment_tips.content: Test your camera by photographing a dime filling the viewfinder - you need excellent close-up capability.

equipment_tips.title: 10x Magnifying Loop
equipment_tips.content: A 10-powered loop is very handy for some identification issues.

equipment_tips.title: Heat-Bent Trowel
equipment_tips.content: A six-inch trowel with the end two inches heat bent to a 45-degree angle is lightweight and efficient for digging.

equipment_tips.title: Paint Handles Orange
equipment_tips.content: Paint trowel handles fluorescent orange for easy recovery if dropped.

equipment_tips.title: Carry Fels Naptha Soap
equipment_tips.content: Fels Naptha soap (laundry section) washes off plant irritants like poison ivy within minutes of contact.

equipment_tips.title: Binoculars Multi-Use
equipment_tips.content: Waterproof binoculars serve multiple purposes: viewing distant foliage, documentation, and appearing non-threatening to authorities.

preparation_tips.title: Pokeweed Requires Multiple Boilings
preparation_tips.content: Pokeweed must be boiled at least twice, if not three times. Single boiling causes illness.

preparation_tips.title: Cook Grubs Over Low Heat
preparation_tips.content: Grubs explode within a second in very hot fat. Always use low heat.

preparation_tips.title: Puffball Safety Check
preparation_tips.content: Always cut puffball from top to bottom. Interior must be marshmallow soft, pure white (never dark), thin outer skin, and no outline of mushroom inside.

preparation_tips.title: Agave Handling Caution
preparation_tips.content: Raw agave juice causes dermatitis via calcium oxalates. DO NOT CUT WITH A CHAIN SAW. WEAR EYE PROTECTION.

preparation_tips.title: Water Hyacinth Source Matters
preparation_tips.content: Harvest only from clean water sources - never downstream from mines. The plant absorbs pollutants readily.

preparation_tips.title: Wild Rice Harvest Window
preparation_tips.content: Harvest mid-August to mid-September when plants are still green. If they are brown, you're too late.

preparation_tips.title: Wild Rice Processing
preparation_tips.content: Sun dry at least two days, then parch. Hull immediately after parching or grains reabsorb moisture. Keep away from sand.

preparation_tips.title: Jerusalem Artichoke Digestive Prep
preparation_tips.content: Build tolerance by eating small portions for 3-4 days before consuming larger servings. The inulin causes gas initially.

preparation_tips.title: Kochia Nitrate Warning
preparation_tips.content: Like spinach, kochia can accumulate nitrates. Those avoiding spinach should avoid kochia too.

preparation_tips.title: Wokas Processing Time
preparation_tips.content: Place ripe pond lily seed pods in water for EXACTLY three weeks to remove bitterness through enzyme action.

identification_tips.title: Sunflower Sun Tracking
identification_tips.content: Young sunflower heads track the sun east-to-west daily, returning eastward overnight. Mature plants stop turning but face east.

identification_tips.title: Wild Rice vs Giant Cut Grass
identification_tips.content: Female flower parts are stiff and erect; male parts droop. This distinguishes wild rice from lookalike Giant Cut Grass.

identification_tips.title: Poplar Identification
identification_tips.content: Poplar twigs have a bitter, aspirin-like taste. Leaves are triangular with flattened base and curved, gland-tipped teeth.

identification_tips.title: Acorn Grub vs Moth
identification_tips.content: Seek short, legless grubs that are tan-colored and fat in the middle. Acorn moth caterpillars have six front legs and are long/skinny.

identification_tips.title: Water Hyacinth vs Frog Bit
identification_tips.content: Water hyacinth has black feathery roots with bulbous float at stem base. Frog Bit has white roots and no bulbous growth.

identification_tips.title: Finding Palmetto Grubs
identification_tips.content: Look for dying palm trees with dead, bent, or distorted growing tips. Young heart leaves pull out easily and show tunneling marks.

seasonal_tips.title: Acorn Grub Peak Season
seasonal_tips.content: Peak season is September, particularly after heavy August rains.

seasonal_tips.title: New Jersey Tea Harvest Time
seasonal_tips.content: Best harvest time is early summer when plant blossoms.

seasonal_tips.title: Agave Harvest Timing
seasonal_tips.content: Harvest stalk before the plant blooms in summer. Old and tough plants are best - opposite of typical foraging rule.

seasonal_tips.title: High Bush Cranberry Frost Effect
seasonal_tips.content: Some think berries taste better after one or two frosts, others think they are best collected before a frost.

seasonal_tips.title: Jerusalem Artichoke Harvest
seasonal_tips.content: Pick tubers two weeks after flowers fade. Flavor improves after frost exposure.

nutritional_info.title: Grub Nutritional Value
nutritional_info.content: Ten finger-sized witchetty grubs meet daily caloric/nutritional needs for adults. Palmetto grubs contain 3-7% protein and 10-30% fat.

nutritional_info.title: Water Hyacinth Nutrition
nutritional_info.content: Contains vitamins A, B1, B2, and betacarotene; 18.7% protein, 17.1% fiber, 36.6% carbohydrates.

nutritional_info.title: Water Spinach Nutrition
nutritional_info.content: 48% carbohydrates, 24% proteins, 13% ash; rich in vitamins A, C, E.

nutritional_info.title: Kochia Protein Content
nutritional_info.content: Protein ranges from 11 to 22%, decreasing as the plant matures.
